lesson.subject: language
lesson.title: The Cyrillic Code I
lesson.subtitle: True Friends & False Friends
lesson.description: Recognize Cyrillic letters that look like Latin letters
objectives: Recognize Cyrillic letters that look like Latin letters
Identify 'False Friend' letters that look Latin but sound different
Read international words using learned letters
Understand basic Noun Gender (Masculine, Feminine, Neuter)
Form simple sentences using "This is" and "My"

sections.name: –í—Å—Ç—É–ø
sections.content:
## warm-up

### Why Learn Cyrillic?

Ukrainian uses the Cyrillic alphabet - 33 letters total. Good news: many look familiar! This module covers 18 letters you can learn quickly.

The key insight: some letters LOOK like English but make DIFFERENT sounds. We call these "False Friends" - they'll trick you if you're not careful!

> üîç **Myth Buster: "Cyrillic is Russian"**
>
> Many people think Cyrillic = Russian. **Wrong!** The Cyrillic alphabet was created in the **9th century in Bulgaria** by disciples of Saints Cyril and Methodius. It spread throughout the Slavic world - Russia adopted it centuries later. Today, Cyrillic is used by dozens of languages including Ukrainian, Bulgarian, Serbian, Mongolian, and many others. Russian doesn't own it!

> üí° **Did You Know?**
>
> Ukrainian Cyrillic has **unique letters** that don't exist in Russian:
> - **–á** (yi) - only Ukrainian has this!
> - **–Ñ** (ye) - Ukrainian form
> - **“ê** (hard g) - restored after independence
>
> When you see these letters, you know it's Ukrainian, not Russian!

## presentation

### Group 1: True Friends (7 letters)

These letters look AND sound like their Latin equivalents:

| Letter | Sound | Example |
|--------|-------|---------|
| –ê –∞ | A (as in "father") | –º–ê–º–ê |
| –ï –µ | E (as in "bet") | –º–ï—Ç—Ä–æ |
| –Ü —ñ | I (as in "machine") | —Ç–∞–∫—Å–Ü |
| –û –æ | O (as in "hot") | —Ñ–û—Ç–û |
| –ö –∫ | K | –ö–∞—Ñ–µ |
| –ú –º | M | –ú–∞–º–∞ |
| –¢ —Ç | T | –¢–∞—Ç–æ |

Trust these! They work exactly as you'd expect.

> üìú **History Bite: The Greek Connection**
>
> Both the Latin alphabet (which English uses) and Cyrillic come from the **Greek alphabet**. That's why letters like A, E, K, M, O, and T look the same - they share Greek ancestors! When you see these "True Friends," you're seeing evidence of how alphabets evolved from ancient Greece to modern times.

### Group 2: False Friends (6 letters)

DANGER! These look Latin but sound completely different:

| Letter | Looks like | Actually sounds like |
|--------|------------|---------------------|
| –í –≤ | B | V (as in "van") |
| –ù –Ω | H | N (as in "no") |
| –† —Ä | P | R (rolled, as in Spanish) |
| –° —Å | C | S (as in "sun") |
| –£ —É | Y | U (as in "flute") |
| –• —Ö | X | KH (as in German "Bach") |

Memorize these! They cause the most confusion for beginners.

> ‚ö° **Pro Tip: Remember the False Friends**
>
> Each letter looks like one thing but sounds like another:
> - **–í** looks like B ‚Üí sounds like **V** (as in Violin)
> - **–ù** looks like H ‚Üí sounds like **N** (as in Noon)
> - **–†** looks like P ‚Üí sounds like **R** (rolled, like Spanish)
> - **–°** looks like C ‚Üí sounds like **S** (always soft)
> - **–£** looks like Y ‚Üí sounds like **U** (as in flUte)
> - **–•** looks like X ‚Üí sounds like **KH** (German "Bach")
>
> Practice these daily until they become automatic!

> üéØ **Fun Fact: Why the Confusion?**
>
> The "False Friends" exist because Cyrillic and Latin alphabets evolved separately from Greek. The Greek letter **Œ°** (rho) became **R** in Latin but **–†** in Cyrillic - same origin, different evolution! Similarly, Greek **Œù** (nu) became **N** in Latin but looks like **–ù** in Cyrillic.

### Group 3: New But Easy (6 letters)

These don't exist in Latin but are straightforward:

| Letter | Sound | Memory tip |
|--------|-------|------------|
| –ë –± | B | Belly with a belt |
| –î –¥ | D | Like a house |
| –ó –∑ | Z | Like the number 3 |
| –õ –ª | L | Like a tent |
| –ü –ø | P | Like a doorway/portal |
| –§ —Ñ | F | Like a person with arms out |

> üîó **Language Link: B and V**
>
> Notice that Ukrainian has **two** letters for B-sounds: **–ë** (true B) and **–í** (V sound). English only has one! This is why some Ukrainian words borrowed into English seem to swap B and V. For example, the name "Volodymyr" (–í–æ–ª–æ–¥–∏–º–∏—Ä) is sometimes written "Vladimir" because Russian –í sounds like V to English ears.

## grammar

### Introduction to Nouns & Gender

In Ukrainian, every noun has a **gender**. It's not about biology (mostly) - it's about the **ending** of the word.

| Gender | Ending | Example | My (M/F/N) |
|--------|--------|---------|------------|
| **Masculine** | Consonant | –ø–∞—Ä–∫, –±—Ä–∞—Ç | **–º—ñ–π** –ø–∞—Ä–∫ |
| **Feminine** | -–∞ / -—è | –º–∞–º–∞, –≤—ñ–∑–∞ | **–º–æ—è** –º–∞–º–∞ |
| **Neuter** | -–æ / -–µ | –º–µ—Ç—Ä–æ, —Ñ–æ—Ç–æ | **–º–æ—î** —Ñ–æ—Ç–æ |

> üß† **Pattern Recognition**
> - If it ends in a **Consonant** (K, T, R, N...), it's usually **Masculine**.
> - If it ends in **-A**, it's usually **Feminine**.
> - If it ends in **-O**, it's usually **Neuter**.

### "This is..." (–¶–µ)

To say "This is...", you just say **–¶–µ** (Tse). No "is" verb needed!

- **–¶–µ** –ø–∞—Ä–∫. (This is a park.)
- **–¶–µ** –º–∞–º–∞. (This is mom.)

Combine it with "my":
- **–¶–µ –º—ñ–π** —Ç–µ–ª–µ—Ñ–æ–Ω. (This is my telephone.) - *Masculine (consonant)*
- **–¶–µ –º–æ—è** –ª–∞–º–ø–∞. (This is my lamp.) - *Feminine (-a)*
- **–¶–µ –º–æ—î** —Ä–∞–¥—ñ–æ. (This is my radio.) - *Neuter (-o)*

## practice

### Reading Strategy

When you see a Cyrillic word:
1. Go letter by letter
2. Watch for False Friends (–í=V, –ù=N, –†=R, –°=S, –£=U, –•=KH)
3. Sound it out slowly
4. Many words are cognates - they'll sound familiar!

### Try These Words

Sound out each word. Most are international words you'll recognize:

–ë–ê–ù–ö ‚Üí B-A-N-K ‚Üí bank
–ü–ê–†–ö ‚Üí P-A-R-K ‚Üí park
–ú–ï–¢–†–û ‚Üí M-E-T-R-O ‚Üí metro
–ö–ê–§–ï ‚Üí K-A-F-E ‚Üí caf√©

> üåç **Real World: Cognates Everywhere**
>
> Ukrainian (like all languages) borrows international words. When you visit Ukraine, you'll see signs you can read immediately:
> - **–ë–ê–ù–ö** (bank)
> - **–†–ï–°–¢–û–†–ê–ù** (restaurant)
> - **–ì–û–¢–ï–õ–¨** (hotel)
> - **–ê–ü–¢–ï–ö–ê** (pharmacy - from Greek "apotheke"!)
>
> About 10-15% of everyday Ukrainian words are recognizable cognates. You already know more Ukrainian than you think!

## production

### Reading Challenge

Read these words without looking at transliteration:

1. –ú–ê–ú–ê
2. –¢–ê–¢–û
3. –°–¢–£–î–ï–ù–¢
4. –§–£–¢–ë–û–õ
5. –ú–£–ó–ò–ö–ê

### False Friend Drill

Remember: –ü = P, –† = R, –í = V, –ù = N, –° = S, –• = KH

Read these tricky words:
- –°–£–ü–ï–†–ú–ê–†–ö–ï–¢ (supermarket)
- –†–ï–°–¢–û–†–ê–ù (restaurant)
- –ü–ê–°–ü–û–†–¢ (passport)

> üé≠ **Culture Corner: Names in Cyrillic**
>
> Ukrainian names follow Cyrillic spelling, which sometimes surprises English speakers:
> - **–•–∞—Ä–∫—ñ–≤** (Kharkiv) - the –• makes a "kh" sound
> - **–í–æ–ª–æ–¥–∏–º–∏—Ä** (Volodymyr) - –í is V, not B
> - **–°—Ç–µ–ø–∞–Ω** (Stepan) - –° is S, not "St"
>
> When you see Ukrainian names transliterated to English, you're seeing someone's attempt to represent Cyrillic sounds in Latin letters!

---

---

---

---

---


---


---

level: A1
phase: A1.1
duration: 60
transliteration: full
tags: [alphabet, basics, cyrillic, cognates, gender]
objectives:
  - Recognize Cyrillic letters that look like Latin letters
  - Identify 'False Friend' letters that look Latin but sound different
  - Read international words using learned letters
  - Understand basic Noun Gender (Masculine, Feminine, Neuter)
  - Form simple sentences using "This is" and "My"
grammar:
  - Cyrillic alphabet groups 1-3 (18 letters)
  - Noun Gender Basics (ending patterns)
  - Demonstrative pronoun "–¶–µ" (This is)
  - Possessive pronouns "–ú—ñ–π/–ú–æ—è/–ú–æ—î" (My)
---

| –† —Ä | P | R (rolled, as in Spanish) |

| –£ —É | Y | U (as in "flute") |

> - **–†** looks like P ‚Üí sounds like **R** (rolled, like Spanish)

| –ó –∑ | Z | Like the number 3 |

>

For example, the name "Volodymyr" (–í–æ–ª–æ–¥–∏–º–∏—Ä) is sometimes written "Vladimir" because Russian –í sounds like V to English ears.

## grammar

### Introduction to Nouns & Gender

In Ukrainian, every noun has a **gender**. It's not about biology (mostly) - it's about the **ending** of the word.

| Gender | Ending | Example | My (M/F/N) |
|--------|--------|---------|------------|

| **Feminine** | -–∞ / -—è | –º–∞–º–∞, –≤—ñ–∑–∞ | **–º–æ—è** –º–∞–º–∞ |
| **Neuter** | -–æ / -–µ | –º–µ—Ç—Ä–æ, —Ñ–æ—Ç–æ | **–º–æ—î** —Ñ–æ—Ç–æ |

## production

### Reading Challenge

Read these words without looking at transliteration:

1. –ú–ê–ú–ê
2. –¢–ê–¢–û
3. –°–¢–£–î–ï–ù–¢
4. –§–£–¢–ë–û–õ
5. –ú–£–ó–ò–ö–ê

### False Friend Drill

Remember: –ü = P, –† = R, –í = V, –ù = N, –° = S, –• = KH

Read these tricky words:
- –°–£–ü–ï–†–ú–ê–†–ö–ï–¢ (supermarket)
- –†–ï–°–¢–û–†–ê–ù (restaurant)

# Activities

## fill-in: False Friends - What Sound?

> The letter looks Latin but sounds different! Choose the correct sound.

1. The Ukrainian letter **–†** makes the sound ___.
   > [!answer] [r] like "run"
   > [!options] [p] like "park" | [r] like "run" | [b] like "bat" | [d] like "dog"

2. The Ukrainian letter **–í** makes the sound ___.
   > [!answer] [v] like "van"
   > [!options] [b] like "bat" | [v] like "van" | [w] like "win" | [f] like "fan"

3. The Ukrainian letter **–ù** makes the sound ___.
   > [!answer] [n] like "no"
   > [!options] [h] like "hat" | [n] like "no" | [m] like "map" | [ng] like "sing"

4. The Ukrainian letter **–°** makes the sound ___.
   > [!answer] [s] like "sun"
   > [!options] [k] like "cat" | [s] like "sun" | [ch] like "chin" | [sh] like "ship"

5. The Ukrainian letter **–•** makes the sound ___.
   > [!answer] [kh] like Scottish "loch"
   > [!options] [x] like "box" | [h] like "hat" | [kh] like Scottish "loch" | [k] like "cat"

6. The Ukrainian letter **–£** makes the sound ___.
   > [!answer] [u] like "moon"
   > [!options] [y] like "yes" | [u] like "moon" | [oo] like "book" | [ju] like "you"

7. The word "—Å—Ç—É–¥–µ–Ω—Ç" sounds like ___.
   > [!answer] stoo-DENT
   > [!options] STOO-dent | stoo-DENT | STYOO-dent | stu-DYENT

8. The word "–º–µ—Ç—Ä–æ" sounds like ___.
   > [!answer] meh-TRO
   > [!options] MEE-tro | MET-ro | meh-TRO | may-TROH

9. In "–¥–æ–∫—Ç–æ—Ä", the letter "–æ" is pronounced ___.
   > [!answer] always as [o], never reduced
   > [!options] as [a] like in Russian | always as [o], never reduced | sometimes [o], sometimes [a] | silent

10. The word "–ø–∞—Ä–∫" ends with the sound ___.
    > [!answer] [k] - final consonants stay voiced
    > [!options] [g] - voiced at the end | [k] - final consonants stay voiced | silent - not pronounced | [kh] - aspirated

## fill-in: Miy, Moya, or Moye?

> Choose the correct possessive pronoun based on the gender.

1. –¶–µ ___ –º–∞–º–∞. (Mom - feminine)
   > [!answer] –º–æ—è
   > [!options] –º—ñ–π | –º–æ—è | –º–æ—î

2. –¶–µ ___ —Ç–∞—Ç–æ. (Dad - masculine)
   > [!answer] –º—ñ–π
   > [!options] –º—ñ–π | –º–æ—è | –º–æ—î

3. –¶–µ ___ —Ñ–æ—Ç–æ. (Photo - neuter)
   > [!answer] –º–æ—î
   > [!options] –º—ñ–π | –º–æ—è | –º–æ—î

4. –¶–µ ___ —Ç–µ–ª–µ—Ñ–æ–Ω. (Telephone - masculine)
   > [!answer] –º—ñ–π
   > [!options] –º—ñ–π | –º–æ—è | –º–æ—î

5. –¶–µ ___ –ª–∞–º–ø–∞. (Lamp - feminine)
   > [!answer] –º–æ—è
   > [!options] –º—ñ–π | –º–æ—è | –º–æ—î

6. –¶–µ ___ —Ä–∞–¥—ñ–æ. (Radio - neuter)
   > [!answer] –º–æ—î
   > [!options] –º—ñ–π | –º–æ—è | –º–æ—î

7. –¶–µ ___ –¥–æ–∫—Ç–æ—Ä. (Doctor - masculine)
   > [!answer] –º—ñ–π
   > [!options] –º—ñ–π | –º–æ—è | –º–æ—î

8. –¶–µ ___ –∑–µ–±—Ä–∞. (Zebra - feminine)
   > [!answer] –º–æ—è
   > [!options] –º—ñ–π | –º–æ—è | –º–æ—î

## unjumble: Build the Sentence

> Arrange the words in the correct order. Sentences range from 4-6 words.

1. –º—ñ–π / –¥–æ–∫—Ç–æ—Ä / –¢–∞—Ç–æ / –º—ñ–π
   > [!answer] –ú—ñ–π —Ç–∞—Ç–æ –º—ñ–π –¥–æ–∫—Ç–æ—Ä.
   > (My dad is my doctor.) [4 words]

2. —î / –¢–∞–º / –≤–µ–ª–∏–∫–∏–π / –ø–∞—Ä–∫
   > [!answer] –¢–∞–º —î –≤–µ–ª–∏–∫–∏–π –ø–∞—Ä–∫.
   > (There is a big park.) [4 words]

3. –º–∞–º–∞ / –ú–æ—è / –≤–¥–æ–º–∞ / —Ç—É—Ç
   > [!answer] –ú–æ—è –º–∞–º–∞ —Ç—É—Ç –≤–¥–æ–º–∞.
   > (My mom is here at home.) [4 words]

4. –Ω–æ–≤–∏–π / –¶–µ / –º—ñ–π / —Ç–µ–ª–µ—Ñ–æ–Ω
   > [!answer] –¶–µ –º—ñ–π –Ω–æ–≤–∏–π —Ç–µ–ª–µ—Ñ–æ–Ω.
   > (This is my new phone.) [4 words]

5. –¢–∞–º / –±–∞–Ω–∫ / —ñ / —î / –ø–∞—Ä–∫
   > [!answer] –¢–∞–º —î –±–∞–Ω–∫ —ñ –ø–∞—Ä–∫.
   > (There is a bank and park.) [5 words]

6. –º–æ—î / —Ñ–æ—Ç–æ / —Å—Ç–∞—Ä–µ / –¶–µ
   > [!answer] –¶–µ –º–æ—î —Å—Ç–∞—Ä–µ —Ñ–æ—Ç–æ.
   > (This is my old photo.) [4 words]

7. —Ç–µ–∞—Ç—Ä / –¢—É—Ç / —î / –≤–µ–ª–∏–∫–∏–π
   > [!answer] –¢—É—Ç —î –≤–µ–ª–∏–∫–∏–π —Ç–µ–∞—Ç—Ä.
   > (Here is a big theater.) [4 words]

8. —Ç–∞–∫—Å—ñ / —Ç–∞–º / –ú–æ—î / —î
   > [!answer] –ú–æ—î —Ç–∞–∫—Å—ñ —î —Ç–∞–º.
   > (My taxi is there.) [4 words]

9. —ñ / —Ç–∞—Ç–æ / –º–∞–º–∞ / –¶–µ / –º–æ—è / –º—ñ–π
   > [!answer] –¶–µ –º—ñ–π —Ç–∞—Ç–æ —ñ –º–æ—è –º–∞–º–∞.
   > (This is my dad and my mom.) [6 words]

10. –ª–∞–º–ø–∞ / –ú–æ—è / —ñ / —Ç—É—Ç / —Ñ–æ—Ç–æ
    > [!answer] –ú–æ—è –ª–∞–º–ø–∞ —ñ —Ñ–æ—Ç–æ —Ç—É—Ç.
    > (My lamp and photo are here.) [5 words]

## match-up: Match the Pairs

> Match Ukrainian words to their English meanings.

| Left | Right |
|------|-------|
| —Ç–µ–∞—Ç—Ä | theater |
| —Ç–µ–ª–µ—Ñ–æ–Ω | telephone |
| –¥–æ–∫—Ç–æ—Ä | doctor |
| –ª–∞–º–ø–∞ | lamp |
| –∑–µ–±—Ä–∞ | zebra |
| –∫–ª–∞—Å | class |
| –ø–ª–∞–Ω | plan |
| —Å–ø–æ—Ä—Ç | sport |
| —Å—Ç–∞—Ä—Ç | start |
| —Å—Ç–æ–ø | stop |

## group-sort: Letter Classification

> Sort these Cyrillic letters into the correct categories.

### True Friends (Same look AND sound)
- –ê
- –û
- –ö
- –ú
- –¢
- –ï
- –Ü

### False Friends (Look similar, different sound)
- –í (looks like B, sounds like V)
- –ù (looks like H, sounds like N)
- –† (looks like P, sounds like R)
- –° (looks like C, sounds like S)
- –£ (looks like Y, sounds like U)
- –• (looks like X, sounds like KH)

### New Letters (Unique to Cyrillic)
- –ë (B sound)
- –î (D sound)
- –ó (Z sound)
- –õ (L sound)
- –ü (P sound)
- –§ (F sound)

## quiz: Cyrillic Alphabet Rules

> Test your understanding of the Ukrainian alphabet and False Friends.

1. The letter **–†** in Ukrainian sounds like:
   - [ ] English "P"
   - [x] English "R" (rolled)
   - [ ] English "B"
   - [ ] English "D"
   > –† is a False Friend - looks like P but sounds like R

2. The letter **–ù** in Ukrainian sounds like:
   - [ ] English "H"
   - [x] English "N"
   - [ ] English "M"
   - [ ] English "Y"
   > –ù is a False Friend - looks like H but sounds like N

3. Which letter is unique to Ukrainian (not found in Russian)?
   - [ ] –ê
   - [ ] –û
   - [x] –á
   - [ ] –ï
   > –á (yi) only exists in Ukrainian alphabet

4. The letter **–í** in Ukrainian sounds like:
   - [ ] English "B"
   - [x] English "V"
   - [ ] English "W"
   - [ ] English "F"
   > –í is a False Friend - looks like B but sounds like V

5. How many letters are in the Ukrainian alphabet?
   - [ ] 26
   - [ ] 30
   - [x] 33
   - [ ] 35
   > Ukrainian has 33 letters (more than English's 26)

6. The letter **–°** in Ukrainian sounds like:
   - [ ] English "K"
   - [x] English "S"
   - [ ] English "C" as in "cat"
   - [ ] English "Z"
   > –° is a False Friend - looks like C but always sounds like S

7. Which are "True Friends" (same look AND sound)?
   - [x] –ê, –û, –ö, –ú, –¢
   - [ ] –í, –ù, –†, –°
   - [ ] –ñ, –®, –©, –ß
   - [ ] –Ñ, –á, –Æ, –Ø
   > True Friends look Latin and sound the same

8. The letter **–•** sounds like:
   - [ ] English "X"
   - [x] "KH" as in "Bach"
   - [ ] English "H"
   - [ ] Silent
   > –• makes a guttural "kh" sound

9. What does the soft sign **–¨** do?
   - [ ] Makes a vowel sound
   - [ ] Makes an "H" sound
   - [x] Softens the preceding consonant
   - [ ] Nothing - it's silent and meaningless
   > –¨ doesn't make a sound but softens consonants

10. Which letters are "iotated vowels" (add Y-sound)?
    - [ ] –ê, –û, –£, –ò
    - [x] –Ñ, –á, –Æ, –Ø
    - [ ] –ï, –Ü, –ò
    - [ ] –ë, –í, –ì
    > Iotated vowels: –Ñ=YE, –á=YI, –Æ=YU, –Ø=YA

## true-false: Alphabet Rules

> Determine if each statement about Ukrainian letters is true or false.

- [x] The Ukrainian letter –† sounds like English "R", not "P".
   > Correct! –† is a False Friend - looks like P but sounds like rolled R.

- [ ] The letter –ù in Ukrainian sounds like English "H".
   > Incorrect. –ù = N sound. It's a False Friend (looks like H).

- [x] The letters –ê, –û, –ö, –ú, –¢ look AND sound the same in English and Ukrainian.
   > Correct! These are "True Friends" - identical in both languages.

- [ ] The letter –í in Ukrainian sounds like English "B".
   > Incorrect. –í = V sound. It's a False Friend (looks like B).

- [x] The letter –° in Ukrainian always sounds like English "S".
   > Correct! –° = S, never the "k" sound of English "C" in "cat".

- [x] Ukrainian has 33 letters, more than English's 26.
   > Correct! Ukrainian alphabet: 33 letters total.

- [ ] The letter –• in Ukrainian sounds like English "X".
   > Incorrect. –• = KH sound (like "ch" in Scottish "loch").

- [x] The letter –Ü in Ukrainian sounds like "ee" in "meet".
   > Correct! –Ü is a True Friend with consistent "ee" pronunciation.

- [ ] All Cyrillic letters that look like Latin letters sound the same.
   > Incorrect. False Friends (–í, –ù, –†, –°, –£, –•) look similar but sound different!

- [x] Learning True Friends first makes reading Ukrainian easier.
   > Correct! Start with identical letters, then learn False Friends.

---

# Letter Groups

## True Friends
–ê –ï –Ü –û –ö –ú –¢

## False Friends
–í –ù –† –° –£ –•

## New Letters
–ë –î –ó –õ –ü –§

---

# Summary

> üí° **What You Learned Today**
>
> - The Cyrillic alphabet comes from Bulgaria, not Russia
> - Ukrainian has 33 letters (you learned 18 today!)
> - **True Friends** (7): Look and sound like Latin
> - **False Friends** (6): Look Latin but sound different - the tricky ones!
> - **New Letters** (6): Unique shapes but easy sounds
> - Many international words are readable with these 18 letters

> üéØ **Coming Next**
>
> In Module 02, you'll learn the remaining 15 letters including:
> - The unique Ukrainian letters –á, –Ñ, and “ê
> - The "soft sign" –¨ that changes how letters sound
> - Cursive/italic forms (some look VERY different!)
